channel.title: Innovation on Time for a Change
channel.description: Recent content in Innovation on Time for a Change

item.title: Fat Macy's restaurant tackles homelessness
item.description: In the UK, Fat Macy’s is a social enterprise that uses its restaurant and events catering business to train and support Londoners living in temporary accommodation and help them move into their own homes.

item.title: Free skateboard lessons to fight crime and violence
item.description: Brazilian skateboarder Sandro Soares—also known as Testinha—and his wife Leila Vieira dos Santos created Social Skate, an NGO that offers free skate lessons to young people in Poa, near Sau Paulo.

item.title: Second chance classes put young Ethiopians back to school
item.description: The education charity Luminos Fund launched an accelerated schooling program that helps Ethiopian children between the ages of 8 and 14 resume studies disrupted by conflict, child labour and poverty.

item.title: German startup makes green hydrogen accessible to everyone
item.description: The German startup Enapter designed an award-winning technology that makes emission-free hydrogen accessible to all.

item.title: Home of Hope changes China's perception regarding accessibility
item.description: In Shanghai, Home of Hope is the city’s first dance group that includes only people with paraplegia, aiming to reshape perceptions of accessibility in China.

item.title: Sweden opens the world's first recycling mall
item.description: In Sweden, ReTuna Återbruksgalleria is the world’s first mall that combines a recycling centre with a circular-economy-centric shopping experience.

item.title: American entrepreneur designs a wind-powered wall
item.description: American designer and entrepreneur Joe Doucet created a concept of a wind turbine that fits into a wall.

item.title: How Metropolitan France grows zero-carbon exotic produce
item.description: In France, Les Arts Verts grow tropical produce in greenhouses to reduce the carbon footprint associated with importing food from around the globe.

item.title: Owls replace pesticides in Californian wineries
item.description: Today, 80% of Napa Valley winemakers use owls to control their rodent population, while less than 20% use rodenticide instead.

item.title: A pub lets you pay your beer with old iPhones
item.description: In London, the Trade-Inn pub lets you pay for your food and beverages with electronic waste.

item.title: DroneSeed leverages drone technology to further reforestation efforts
item.description: DroneSeed developed a drone-based technology to reforest lands after wildfires efficiently.

item.title: New hydrogel tablets can purify contaminated water in minutes
item.description: Scientists and engineers at The University of Texas at Austin have created a hydrogel tablet to purify contaminated water rapidly.

item.title: Aether creates the world's first carbon-negative diamonds
item.description: After years of research, Aether Diamonds cracked the technology allowing them to create the world’s first carbon-negative diamonds.

item.title: Furniture made from eelgrass, good for the environment and your health
item.description: The Danish startup Søuld produces eco-friendly building materials from eelgrass.

item.title: Japan wants to harness the energy of super typhoons to reach climate goals
item.description: The Japanese “Typoonshot” project aims to mitigate typhoon-related risks and harness their energy to help the country reach zero carbon emissions by 2050.

item.title: An adoption agency for preloved toys opens in London
item.description: In the UK, Loved Before opened a “soft toy adoption agency” to promote sustainability in the industry and give preloved toys a second life.

item.title: Children's play centre uses algae to clean the air
item.description: The London-based organization EcoLogicStudio designed a children’s play centre called AirBubble that uses algae in solar-powered bioreactors to remove pollutants from the air.

item.title: Virtual Reality is reducing the need for opioids and sedatives
item.description: Across the United States, hospitals rely more and more on Virtual Reality (VR) headsets to relieve their patients’ pain.

item.title: "Chat checkouts" emerge in the Netherlands to fight social isolation
item.description: In the Netherlands, the supermarket chain Jumbo opens tills where clients can take their time and chat instead of rushing to pay for their groceries.

item.title: French startup wants to end microplastics with biodegradable microcapsules
item.description: The French startup Calyxia invented the world’s first customizable, advanced and sustainable microencapsulation technology.

item.title: Waterlight is changing lives in coastal communities
item.description: In Colombia, Wunderman Thompson and the startup E-Dina collaborated on WaterLight, a device that can transform half a litre of salt water into 45 days of light.

item.title: Dog rescue units watch over Italian beaches
item.description: In Italy, 350 canines from the Italian School of Water Rescue Dogs (Scuola Italiana Cani Salvataggio, or SICS) act as lifeguards and watch over 30 of the country’s busiest beaches.

item.title: Goats return to Dublin to fight fires
item.description: In Dublin, city planners hired goats to control weeds on the Howth’s Head peninsula. This creative initiative, which started last year after a fire occurred in the area, goes beyond protecting Ireland’s capital city.

item.title: Nigerian designer upcycles tyres into gorgeous furniture
item.description: Favour Oluma is a Nigerian entrepreneur who creates modern ottomans and coffee tables from old tyres through her company Retyredglam.

item.title: Social enterprise turns the forgotten food of the Sahel into quality foods
item.description: Sahara Sahel Foods is a social enterprise based in Niger that turns the fruits, seeds and leaves of Sahel’s wild trees into quality foods.

item.title: Praan sucks air pollution to use it as raw material
item.description: While studying engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology in the US, Angad Daryani designed a device that captures the pollution from the air so we can turn it into something else.

item.title: This company harnesses solar power to solve the water crisis
item.description: Solar Water PLC created an affordable and sustainable desalination system that produces fresh water from sea water on an industrial scale without causing any emissions.

item.title: ELU, an Egyptian robot that creates water from thin air
item.description: Mahmoud Elkoumy, a mechatronics engineer from Egypt, built ELU, a robot that converts humidity from the air into drinkable water.

item.title: Smart Wheelchair Bro climbs stairs and navigates all terrains
item.description: The Swiss company Scewo designed Bro, an innovative wheelchair that allows people to navigate virtually all terrains and even climb stairs.

item.title: World's first 3D printed school changes the face of education in Madagascar
item.description: In Fianarantsoa, Madagascar, Thinking Hutspartnered with architectural design agency Studio Mortazavi and Finnish company Hyperion Robotics to create the world’s first 3D-printed school.

item.title: GrowStream revolutionizes irrigation in the face of global warming
item.description: The company Responsive Drip Irrigation (RDI) invented an irrigation system that communicates directly with plants to provide them with what they need exactly.

item.title: What if dancing in your living room could lower your electricity bill?
item.description: Researchers from ETH Zürich and the Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology Dübendorf have developed a device embedded in the floor that produces enough energy to power LED light bulbs and small electronics when someone walks on it.

item.title: What if old was the new new?
item.description: Desert cities in the Middle East, Egypt, Pakistan and India have suffered scorching summers for millennia. Still, people managed to survive them long before the invention of air conditioning thanks to natural ventilation methods such as wind-catchers.

item.title: A spray technology acts as sunscreen for cities and keeps us cool
item.description: Pavement Technology Inc. created an “asphalt rejuvenator” that can reduce heat absorption, remove airborne pollutants and make the road more resistant.

item.title: Swedish company produces the world's first "green" steel
item.description: In Sweden, SSAB, LKAB and Vattenfall launched HYBRIT (Hydrogen Breakthrough Ironmaking Technology) to develop a fossil-free value chain for iron and steel production.

item.title: Young inventor develops a microplastic magnet
item.description: Fionn Ferreira, a chemistry student at the University of Groningen in the Netherlands, wants to fight microplastic pollution with magnetic water.

item.title: Modpools upcycles containers into luxurious swimming pools
item.description: The Vancouver-based company Modpools converts shipping containers into swimming pools.

item.title: The Bison Bridge could boost biodiversity in the US
item.description: In the Quad Cities, USA, the Bison Bridge project aims to repurpose Fred Schwengel Memorial Bridge on Interstate I-80 to create a wildlife crossing that provides safe passage for bison herds.

item.title: These stylish wind turbines generate safe and reliable energy in cities
item.description: The Dutch-American company Flower Turbines creates elegant tulip-shaped wind turbines that pose no danger to wildlife and whose noise is undetectable to humans.

item.title: A new pavement technology redirects water into the ground
item.description: The American startup AquiPor designed an alternative pavement material that can absorb rainwater.

item.title: Indian company reverse-engineers plastic to produce fuel
item.description: In India, Rudra Environmental Solutions perfected Thermo Catalytic Depolymerization (TCD), a technique that converts plastic waste into fuel by reversing the plastic production process.

item.title: Local project in Senegal creates circular gardens to boost food security
item.description: In Senegal, a local project is creating hundreds of circular gardens ("Tolou Keur" in Senegal’s Wolof language) that organizers hope will boost food security, reduce regional desertification and engage thousands of community workers.

item.title: Optim Energy leverages kinetic energy for his community
item.description: In Sierra Leone, Jeremiah Thoronka founded Optim Energy to provide people in his community with clean, affordable and reliable energy. His innovative idea is to leverage kinetic energy – the energy objects have when in motion – to generate clean electricity.

item.title: Sri Lanka gives decommissioned buses a second life in the oceans
item.description: The Sri Lankan government gives decommissioned buses a second life by sinking them in the ocean to serve as fish-breeding sites.

item.title: Zelp masks capture cows' methane emissions at the source
item.description: Francisco Norris and his brother Patricio come from a cattle-ranching family in Argentina. In the UK, they founded Zelp, a company that aims to capture methane emissions at the source.

item.title: Sticky labels on fruits and veggies are no longer a necessity
item.description: Dutch fruit and vegetable supplier Nature & More and Swedish supermarket ICA partnered to replace sticky labels on organic products with a laser mark.

item.title: This game lets you clean up the ocean for fun
item.description: Ender Ocean is the first online game dedicated to cleaning up the oceans.

item.title: Environmental DNA, a revolution in wildlife monitoring
item.description: Arnaud Lyet, Conservation Scientist at WWF, studies scarce and elusive wildlife species without actually seeing them thanks to environmental DNA (eDNA), an innovative technology that could revolutionize wildlife monitoring.

item.title: Ivory Coast inaugurates a cocoa-waste-powered biomass plant
item.description: Ivory Coast, the world’s largest cocoa producer, will inaugurate a biomass plant that runs on cocoa waste.

item.title: Mussels turn out to be highly efficient at filtering out plastic
item.description: Pennie Lindeque, Plymouth Marine Laboratory’s Head of Science, turned to nature to address microplastic pollution. Specifically, her team uses mussels to filter water and extract tiny pieces of plastic – smaller than 5 millimetres across – generated from plastic pollution disintegration.

item.title: New graffiti in the UK absorb carbon dioxide from the air
item.description: In London and Bristol, graffiti artists Nerone and Jody Thomas painted murals that absorb carbon dioxide from the air!

item.title: Telemedicine saves lives in rural Honduras
item.description: MosquitiaMed is a volunteer-based organization using telemedicine to improve access to health for the Miskitos community in Honduras.

item.title: A French team uses laser beams and AI to replace pesticides
item.description: A team of researchers in Lyon, France, leveraged their knowledge in artificial intelligence to develop a technology that identifies and removes pests from plants. For their proof of concept, they chose a particularly tough opponent.

item.title: Is underwater gardening the future of agriculture?
item.description: While enjoying a vacation by the Italian sea, Sergio Gamberini wondered whether he could combine his passions for scuba diving and gardening to grow basil underwater.

item.title: Paper Seed Co. creates face masks that turn into trees
item.description: Putting seeds in face masks: that’s the original idea the Indian NGO Paper Seed Co. implemented to fight the pollution generated by the tons of single-use face masks dumped during the pandemic.

item.title: A marine scientist wants to plant 1 million corals
item.description: Although they may look like plants, corals are actually animals. However, they contain plants and secrete minerals, so the confusion is understandable 😅

item.title: Africa's Great Green Wall aims to grow a natural wonder
item.description: Multiple NGOs are currently working on a mammoth project: Africa’s Great Green Wall. This African-led movement has the ambition to grow an 8,000km natural wonder of the world across the entire width of Africa.

item.title: In New Zealand, Supie gives misshapen produce a new life
item.description: Before reaching our grocery stores, fruits and vegetables go through a real beauty pageant. What if we could embrace them as they are, regardless of their appearance?

item.title: Biomass-heated greenhouses might bring food security to Alaska Natives
item.description: Eva Dawn Burk, a graduate student at the University of Alaska Fairbanks, is developing a grassroots project to build biomass-heated greenhouses in rural Native villages in Alaska.

item.title: The Confess Project addresses mental health issues through barbers
item.description: A relationship between a barber and their clients can be special, almost like a family bond. If you watched the amazing TV show “New Amsterdam,” you might already be familiar with the initiative we’ll present now 😊

item.title: This German citizen uses LEGO bricks to improve accessibility in her hometown
item.description: Since LEGO introduced its little bricks to the world, they have never ceased to amaze and spark creativity among kids and adults.

item.title: A Nigerian NGO builds earthquake-proof houses from recycled plastic bottles
item.description: How cool would it be if we could provide affordable and quality housing and help the youth in our communities while preserving the planet?

item.title: Following up on the bees
item.description: Apparently, bees are not only sipping mojitos by the pool but also getting “vaccinated” (*it’s not an actual vaccine, but please bear with us *😇).

item.title: Our favourite movie snack makes a wonderful packaging material
item.description: While enjoying a bucket of popcorn at his favourite movie theatre, Alireza Kharazipour, a researcher at the University of Göttingen, had a flash of genius: replacing polystyrene-based packing peanuts with popcorn!

item.title: Researchers found a way to extract lithium from seawater
item.description: Okay, hang on to your hats because this one literally blew our minds 🤯

item.title: A passive system could clean up 90% of plastic in the ocean
item.description: The Ocean Cleanup is a Dutch non-profit organization aiming to clean up 90% of the floating plastic pollution in our oceans – easy peasy lemon squeezy 🍋.
